case_name: Commissioner of Income Tax v. M/s Straw Products Ltd., Bhopal

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 893 and 894 of 1964 are appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 22, 1961 of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in Misc. Civil Case No. 304 of 1960.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 893 and 894 of 1964. Appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated the August 22, 1961 of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in Misc. Civil Case No. 304 of 1960.

facts.text: The Income Tax Appellate Tribunal referred a question to the Madhya Pradesh High Court under S. 66(1) of the Indian Income Tax Act, 1929.

anchor.surface_text: against the judgment of the High Court of Madhya Pradesh in a reference made to it by the Income Tax Appellate Tribunal, under S. 66(1) of the Indian Income Tax Act, 1929, hereinafter referred to as the Act.

facts.text: The respondent, M/s Straw Products Ltd., Bhopal, is a public limited company incorporated in the erstwhile State of Bhopal in 1939 and given certificate of commencement of business on May 30, 1939.

anchor.surface_text: The relevant facts are these. The respondent, M s Straw Products Ltd., Bhopal, hereinafter called the assessee, is a public limited companypany. It was incorporated in the erstwhile State of Bhopal in 1939 and was given the certificate of companymencement of business on May 30, 1939.

facts.text: On September 20, 1938, the assessee entered into an agreement with the Government of Bhopal obtaining concessions, exclusive licence to manufacture cardboard articles, land on lease on favourable terms, and exempted from payment of customs and other duties.

anchor.surface_text: On September 20, 1938, the assessee entered into an agreement with the Government of Bhopal. Under the agreement the assessee obtained certain companycessions and facilities. The assessee number only got exclusive licence to manufacture card- board articles of all kinds but also got land on lease on favourable terms. It was also exempted from payment of customs and other duties payable to the municipality.

facts.text: Clause 8 of the agreement provided that during 10 years from the date the company takes over the land, the company shall not be liable to pay any sum by way of taxation to the State, subject to certain conditions.

anchor.surface_text: Clause 8 of the agreement is relevant for the purpose of these appeals and is in the following terms Subject to and so far as the State shall number become or become obliged by any Instrument of Accession or Supplementary Instrument under the Government of India Act, 1935, in respect of any Federal Taxation, it is hereby agreed as follows- During the period of I 0 years from the date on which the said Company takes over the land for its business purposes the said Company shall number be liable to pay any sum by way of taxation to the State.

facts.text: It is common ground that the agreement was acted upon and for 10 years the assessee was not called upon to submit returns of income and no assessment was made under the Bhopal Income Tax Act, period expired on October 31, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: It is companymon ground that this agreement was acted upon and for a period of 10 years the assessee was number called upon to submit any returns of income and numberassessment was made on the assessee under the Bhopal Income Tax Act. This period of ten years expired on October 31, 1948.

facts.text: On August 1, 1949, Bhopal merged in India and was formed into a Chief Commissioners Province.

anchor.surface_text: On August 1, 1949, Bhopal merged in India and was formed into a Chief Commissioners Province.

facts.text: For assessment year 1949-50, assessee assessed under Indian Income Tax Act, 1922 on total income for period November 1, 1948 to December 12, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: For the assessment year 1949-50, the assessee was assessed under the Indian Income Tax Act, 1922, on the total income of the period November 1, 1948 to December 12, 1948, as the assessee made up its accounts on the 31st December each year.

facts.text: For assessment years 1952-53 (previous year 1951) and 1953-54 (previous year 1952), Income Tax Officer by orders dated November 27, 1952 and September 30, 1953 allowed depreciation on original cost paid in 1939.

anchor.surface_text: For the assessment years 1952-53 and 1953-54, the assessment years which are the subject matter of this reference  previous years Calendar years 1951 and 1952, respectively , the Income Tax Officer, by orders dated November 27, 1952 and September 30, 1953, allowed depreciation on the machinery, buildings and other assets owned by the assessee on the basis of the original companyt, i.e., the companyt paid in 1939.

facts.text: Income Tax Officer noticed report in Times of India dated March 15, 1957 on Bombay High Court view in Dhrangadhara Chemical Works Limited case.

anchor.surface_text: Subsequently numbericing a report in the Times of India, dated March 15, 1957, giving the view taken by the Bombay High Court in the case of Dhrangadhara Chemical Works Limited 1 , the Income Tax Officer initiated action under S. 34 1  of the Act in respect of these two assessment years.

facts.text: Income Tax Officer by order dated March 4, 1958 recomputed written down value as on 1-1-1951 by determining WDV as on 1-11-1948 under Bhopal Act minus actual depreciation allowed till 31-12-1950, reducing depreciation for 1952-53 from Rs. 2,71,961 to Rs. 1,29,883 and for 1953-54 from Rs. 2,87,285 to Rs. 1,72,673.

anchor.surface_text: After hearing the assessees objections, the Income Tax Officer by his order dated March 4, 1958, held that the written down value of the assets of the companypany will have to be redetermined as on 1-1-1951. This would be done by first determining the written down value of assets as on 1-11-1948 under the Bhopal Income Tax Act. From the written down values so ascertained, all depreciation actually allowed till 31-12-1950 would be deducted. The net figures thus arrived at would show the written down value of the assets in the beginning of the assessment year 1952-53. Consequently, the depreciation of Rs. 2,71,961 allowed in the original assessment for 1952-53 was reduced to Rs. 1,29,883 and for the assessment year 1953-54 the original depreciation allowance of Rs. 2,87,285 was reduced to Rs. 1,72,673.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner on appeal held no excess depreciation allowed in original assessment, no basis for initiating proceedings under s.34, and directed computation on original basis.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Assistant Commissioner, disagreeing with the Income Tax Officer, held on appeal that the assessee had number been allowed excess depreciation allowance as per the original assessment and there was numberbasis for initiating proceedings under s. 34.

facts.text: Appellate Tribunal upheld the order of the Appellate Assistant Commissioner.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Tribunal upheld the order of the Appellate Assistant Commissioner and directed the companyputation of the allowance on that basis.

facts.text: Madhya Pradesh High Court by judgment dated August 22, 1961 answered the question in favour of the basis adopted by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner.

anchor.surface_text: On a reference the High Court by its judgment dated August 22, 1961, answered the question as follows In the circumstances of this case the companyrect basis for companyputing written down value of depreciable assets of the companypany is the one adopted by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner.

facts.text: On August 20, 1962, Central Government made Taxation Laws (Merged States) Removal of Difficulties (Amendment) Order, 1962 amending paragraph 2 by inserting Explanation deeming 'all depreciation actually allowed' to include depreciation that would have been allowed had income not been exempted under agreement with Ruler.

anchor.surface_text: On August 20, 1962, in exercise of the powers companyferred by s. 6 of the Taxation Laws  Extension to Merged States and Amendment  Act, 1949  LXVII of 1949  the Central Government made the following order to amend the Taxation Laws  Merged States   Removal of Difficulties  Order, 1949. ... the Explanation.-For the purpose of this paragraph, expression all depreciation actually allowed tinder any laws or rules of a Merged State means and shall be deemed always to have meant a   b in cases where income had been exempted from tax under any laws or rules in force in a Merged State or under any agreement with a Ruler, the depreciation that would have been allowed had the income number been so exempted.

facts.text: Bhopal Income Tax Act assessments not made on assessee due to agreement exemption.

anchor.surface_text: It is companymon ground that this agreement was acted upon and for a period of 10 years the assessee was number called upon to submit any returns of income and numberassessment was made on the assessee under the Bhopal Income Tax Act.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds that the 1962 Order applies retrospectively and the correct basis for computing WDV as on 1-11-1948 is the one adopted by the Income Tax Officer.

anchor.surface_text: In companyclusion, applying the 1962 order to the facts of this ,case it is clear that the answer to the question referred must be that the companyrect basis for companyputing the written down value of the depreciable assets as on November 1, 1948, is the one which was adopted by the Income Tax Officer.

facts.text: Assessee's accounts made up on 31st December each year.

anchor.surface_text: as the assessee made up its accounts on the 31st December each year.

facts.text: Bombay High Court in Dhrangadhara Chemical Works case held WDV on opening day to be actual cost less depreciation which would have been claimed under Indian IT Act 1922.

anchor.surface_text: In the Dhrangadhara Chemical Works 1  case the Bombay High Court had held that the written down value on the opening day of the account period for which assessment is to be made under the Indian Income Tax Act should be taken at the actual companyt, less the depreciation which companyld have been claimed under the Indian Income Tax Act, 1922.

facts.text: Taxation Laws (Merged States) Removal of Difficulties Order, 1949 came into force on December 3, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: as from December 3, 1949, when the Taxation Laws  Merged States   Removal of Difficulties  Order, 1949, came into force

facts.text: Indian Income Tax Act, 1922 extended to merged states including Bhopal on April 1, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: by S. 3  2  the Indian Income Tax Act, 1922 and the rules and orders made thereunder were extended and brought in force in all the merged States on April 1, 1949.

facts.text: No assessment or notice made under Bhopal Income Tax Act on assessee because no income tax payable due to agreement.

anchor.surface_text: He says that the respondent was number an assessee because under the agreement numberincome tax was payable by it and for this reason numbernotice or assessment had been made under the Bhopal Income Tax Act.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeals accepted, High Court judgment set aside, question answered in favour of Income Tax Officer.

anchor.surface_text: In the result, the appeals are accepted, the judgment of the High Court set aside and the question answered as indicated above.

issues.text: Whether, on the facts of the case and having regard to the provisions of paragraph 2 of the Taxation Laws Merged States Removal of Difficulties Order, 1949, and clause 8 of the Agreement made on 20th September, 1938, between the assessee and the State of Bhopal, the correct basis for computing the written down value of the depreciable assets as at 1-11-1948 is the one which is adopted by the Income Tax Officer or the one adopted by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner?

anchor.surface_text: Whether, on the facts of the case and having regard to the provisions of paragraph 2 of the Taxation Laws  Merged States   Removal of Difficulties  Order, 1949, and clause 8 of the Agreement made on 20th September, 1938, between the assessee and the State of Bhopal, the companyrect basis for companyputing the written down value of the depreciable assets as at 1- 11-1948 is the one which is adopted by the Income Tax Officer or the one adopted by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner?

issues.text: Whether the expression 'all depreciation actually allowed under any laws or rules of a merged State' occurring in para 2 of the Taxation Laws Merged States Removal of Difficulties Order, 1949, meant allowable under the provisions of the said laws or rules even if not actually given effect to.

arguments.claim: The High Court was wrong in answering the question in favour of the assessee; the expression 'actually allowed under any laws or rules of a merged State' occurring in para 2 of the Taxation Laws (Merged States) Removal of Difficulties Order, 1949, meant allowable under the provisions of the said laws or rules even if the income was exempted.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. A. V. Viswanatha Sastri, the learned counsel for the Revenue, urges before us that the High Court was wrong in answering the question in favour of the assessee. He urges that the expression actually allowed under any laws or rules of a merged State occurring in para 2 of the Taxation Laws  Merged States   Removal of Difficulties  Order, 1949, meant allowable under the provisions of the said laws or rules.

arguments.claim: If the income of an assessee is exempted from taxation for a certain number of years, the assessee must be deemed to have claimed depreciation and deemed to have been allowed depreciation according to the provisions of the said laws or rules.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to give such an artificial meaning to the expression all depreciation actually allowed under any laws or rules, and we agree with the High Court that the expression actually allowed is unambiguous and connotes the idea that the allowance was actually given effect to.

arguments.claim: Tribunal/High Court must apply relevant law as amended retrospectively if applicable to transaction and question wide enough; High Court bound to do so.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, following this judgment, we must hold that Mr. Sastri is entitled to rely on the 1962 order and it is our duty to answer the reference in accordance with the amendment made by the order, unless the question referred is not couched in terms of sufficient amplitude...

arguments.claim: 1962 Order not ultra vires; equivalent to amendment of IT Act for merged states; binding on ITO.

anchor.surface_text: We are not able to sustain the distinction sought to be made by Mr. Desai. The order is in effect an amendment of the Indian Income Tax Act insofar as it is applicable to the merged States.

arguments.claim: Correct basis for WDV as on 1-11-1948 is one adopted by ITO, applying 1962 Order.

anchor.surface_text: In conclusion, applying the 1962 order to the facts of this case it is clear that the answer to the question referred must be that the correct basis for computing the written down value of the depreciable assets as on November 1, 1948, is the one which was adopted by the Income Tax Officer.

arguments.claim: No basis for initiating proceedings under s.34 as no excess depreciation allowed originally; 'actually allowed' cannot imply mental phenomenon.

arguments.court_reasoning: 1962 Order retrospectively deems prior depreciation, justifying recomputation.

holdings.text: The correct basis for computing the written down value of the depreciable assets as on November 1, 1948, is the one which was adopted by the Income Tax Officer.

anchor.surface_text: In conclusion, applying the 1962 order to the facts of this ,case it is clear that the answer to the question referred must be that the correct basis for computing the written down value of the depreciable assets as on November 1, 1948, is the one which was adopted by the Income Tax Officer.

holdings.reasoning_summary: 1962 Order retrospectively deems 'all depreciation actually allowed' to include depreciation that would have been allowed had income not been exempted under agreement; applies to facts.

holdings.text: The expression 'actually allowed under any laws or rules of a merged State' in para 2 of the 1949 Order unambiguously means depreciation actually given effect to, not merely allowable.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to give such an artificial meaning to the expression all depreciation actually allowed under any laws or rules, and we agree with the High Court that the expression actually allowed is unambiguous and connotes the idea that the allowance was actually given effect to.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plain and unambiguous language; contrasts with deeming provision in Explanation to s.10(5) IT Act 1922.

holdings.text: Supreme Court must apply retrospectively amended law to reference/appeal if law applies to transaction and question couched in sufficient amplitude.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, following this judgment, we must hold that Mr. Sastri is entitled to rely on the 1962 order and it is our duty to answer the reference in accordance with the amendment made by the order, unless the question referred is not couched in terms of sufficient amplitude to cover an enquiry into the question in the light of the amended law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Following precedent in Commissioner of Sales Tax v. Bijli Cotton Mills; legislative intent requires applying amended law.

holdings.text: Challenge to vires of 1962 Order not entertainable in this proceeding.

anchor.surface_text: we refused to allow him to develop these objections.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Following K.S. Venkataraman v. State of Madras; order equivalent to amendment of IT Act, binding on officers; courts not 'creatures' distinction rejected.

holdings.text: Assessee's income exempted from tax under agreement with Ruler of Bhopal, falling within cl.(b) of Explanation to 1962 Order.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to sustain this contention. The definition of assessee must mean a person by whom income tax is payable under the Bhopal Act. If it had not been for the agreement, the respondent would have been liable to pay tax and it is the agreement alone which exempted it from taxation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Agreement exempted liability under Bhopal IT Act; assessee otherwise liable as person by whom tax payable.

holdings.text: 1962 Order has retrospective effect from December 3, 1949, and applies to assessments for 1952-53 and 1953-54.

anchor.surface_text: We see no force in this contention because the terms of the order are plain and if it is deemed, as directed by the order, that the expression actually allowed under any laws or rules of a merged State should have the meaning ascribed to it by the Explanation, as from December 3, 1949, when the Taxation Laws (Merged States) Removal of Difficulties Order, 1949, came into force, the Explanation must apply to the assessments for the year 1952-53 and 1953-54.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Explicit deeming language 'shall be deemed always to have meant'; plain terms.

holdings.text: Referred question couched in terms of sufficient amplitude to cover application of 1962 Order retrospectively.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Words 'having regard to' para 2 include amended para 2; substance covers ITO vs AAC basis.

holdings.text: 1962 Order is in effect an amendment of the Indian Income Tax Act for merged states and binding on Income Tax Officer.

anchor.surface_text: The order is in effect an amendment of the Indian Income Tax Act insofar as it is applicable to the merged States. If it had not been for the order, only the provisions of s. 10(5) of the Act would have been applied for the purpose of working out depreciation.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Directs different rule for depreciation computation; statutory direction under s.6 of 1949 Act.

anchor.surface_text: In the Dhrangadhra Chemical Works 1  case the Bombay High Court had held that the written down value on the opening day of the account period for which assessment is to be made under the Indian Income Tax Act should be taken at the actual cost, less the depreciation which would have been claimed under the Indian Income Tax Act, 1922.

precedents.cited_proposition: written down value on the opening day of the account period for which assessment is to be made under the Indian Income Tax Act should be taken at the actual cost, less the depreciation which would have been claimed under the Indian Income Tax Act, 1922

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Sales Tax, U.P. v. Bijli Cotton Mills, Hathras 1

anchor.surface_text: Commissioner of Sales Tax, U.P. v. Bijli Cotton Mills, Hathras 1 . Shah, J., speaking for the Court observed as follows Undoubtedly the Tribunal called upon to decide a taxing dispute must apply the relevant law applicable to a particular transaction to which the problem relates,

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Sales Tax, U.P. v. Bijli Cotton Mills
precedents.cited_proposition: when a question has been referred to the High Court and in the meanwhile the law has been amended with retrospective operation, it would be the duty of the High Court to apply the law so amended if it applies
precedents.cited_holding: Undoubtedly the Tribunal called upon to decide a taxing dispute must apply the relevant law applicable to a particular transaction to which the problem relates, and that law normally is the law applicable as on the date on which the transaction in dispute has taken place. If the law which the Tribunal seeks to apply to the dispute is amended, so as to make the law applicable to the transaction in dispute, it would be bound to decide the question in the light of the law so amended. Similarly, when the question has been referred to the High Court and in the meanwhile the law has been amended with retrospective operation, it would be the duty of the High Court to apply the law so amended if it applies.

anchor.surface_text: In conclusion, applying the 1962 order to the facts of this ,case it is clear that the answer to the question referred must be that the correct basis for computing the written down value of the depreciable assets as on November 1, 1948, is the one which was adopted by the Income Tax Officer.
In the result, the appeals are accepted, the judgment of the High Court set aside and the question answered as indicated above.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to give such an artificial meaning to the expression all depreciation actually allowed under any laws or rules, and we agree with the High Court that the expression actually allowed is unambiguous and connotes the idea that the allowance was actually given effect to.
In the result, the appeals are accepted, the judgment of the High Court set aside and the question answered as indicated above.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to sustain this contention. The definition of assessee must mean a person by whom income tax is payable under the Bhopal Act. If it had not been for the agreement, the respondent would have been liable to pay tax and it is the agreement alone which exempted it from taxation.
In the result, the appeals are accepted, the judgment of the High Court set aside and the question answered as indicated above.

anchor.surface_text: We see no force in this contention because the terms of the order are plain and if it is deemed, as directed by the order, that the expression actually allowed under any laws or rules of a merged State should have the meaning ascribed to it by the Explanation, as from December 3, 1949, when the Taxation Laws (Merged States) Removal of Difficulties Order, 1949, came into force, the Explanation must apply to the assessments for the year 1952-53 and 1953-54.
In the result, the appeals are accepted, the judgment of the High Court set aside and the question answered as indicated above.
